author: Cracker77
body:
Debt Threat: Corporate debt is at a record level of $10 Trillion. AAPL has a Debt-to-Equity Ratio of 1.21, and that was reported before the market took a crap. Over half of "investment quality" bonds are now rated BBB, the the lowest investment grade rating available. Corporate cash holdings have dropped to $1.69 Trillion. The US Debt-to-GDP Ratio is 107% .

Consumer Debt is at a record high of $13.95 trillion. Meanwhile, the Prime Age (working age) Employment Ratio has not returned to pre-recession levels. If you look at personal savings rate by income quintile, only the top 20% are saving more than 4%. the bottom 60% aren't saving anything at all. this is largely because the majority of income growth has been in the top 20%. Even the average including the top 20% is only 8%, still historically low.

The equity market cap-to-GDP ratio is at an all-time high, above 200%. The Price-to-Earnings-Growth Ratio (PEG) is at it's highest ever.

In other words, spending and prices have become decouples from actual productivity and earnings. With high debt, low savings, and low credit ratings, both consumers and corporations face default if they have a minor hiccup in revenue.

Note: These numbers rely on the best available data, based on large numbers of tests, available from the WHO and academic sources. they could change as more information comes in from other countries.

Disease threat: In China, the In China, the overall CFR for COVID-19 was 17.3% for cases before they improved standards of care (access to sophisticated medical equipment and trained personal); it then dropped to 0.7%. The much heard 2.3% Case Fatality Rate is an average between these two. This explains the variance in CFR, and why countries such as South Korea, which had preparation and foreknowledge, have a lower CFR.

The disease has a 1 to 14 day incubation rate. This explains the variance in apparent asymptomatic rates (diseases in incubation appear asymptomatic). Hundred of thousands of tests have been conducted in South Korea; the WHO reported that China produced millions of tests. Some cases, such as the first Italy, have shown several weeks of no symptoms before becoming severely ill. This makes it difficult to control the spread.

The data from both China & South Korea seem to support that about 80.9% of cases are mild, 13.8% of cases become severe, and 4.7% become critical. The remaining 0.6% may be asymptomatic. The sum of severe & critical cases is 18.5‬%, close to the 17.3% early CFR in China, suggesting that those people would die without significant supportive care. This care includes: oxygen production and breathing apparatus to support respiratory failure, IVs & vasopressor medication to support septic shock, and dialysis to support kidney failure. The median time to recover is 3-6 weeks for patients with severe or critical disease.

This suggests that about 20% of those infected will need about 4.5 weeks of intensive care. The hospitalization rate for the flu is only 1%.

The overall CFR rate (including all ages and comorbidity statuses) for seasonal flu is about 0.1%. The CFR for COVID-19 ranges from 0.2% for peole in their 20s & 30s, 0.4% for people in their 40s, 1.3% for people in their 50s, 3.6% for people in their 60s, 8.0% for people in their 70s, to 14.8% for people over 80.

CFRs vary by comorbidity. For those with no comorbidity (otherwise in good health), the CFR is 0.9%. Remember that the flu is only 0.1% overall, which lumps in those with comorbidities. Those with diabetes have a CFR of 7.3%, those with hypertension have a CFR of 6.0%, those cardiovascular disease have a CFR of 10.5%.

So, the fatality of the disease ranges from twice as deadly as the overall rate for flu for the healthiest people, to 148 times as deadly as the overall rate for those over 70. It's significantly more likely to result in hospitalization, and that hospitalization will be longer.

The disease appears to have an R0 of about 2.5 without "intense quarantine and social distancing measures". most epidemiologists, and other relevant experts, don't think the world could maintain for the 6 months to a year necessary to develop a vaccine. Current estimates by epidemiologists range from 20% to 70% of adults being infected within a year, depending on control measures. Washington State Department of Health officials stated that they expect to see more cases of COVID-19 in the coming months than cases of flu.

Quarantine and Control Measures Impact: If we want to prevent that millions of people being infected thing from happening, we could do this. The effect on productivity and demand would be tremendous. Additionally, transaction costs go way up; it's difficult to conduct business when you're in different quarantine zones. Their are also multiple legal and political hurdles.

Disease Impact: 20% hospitalization of 20% infected of 209.1 Million adults in the US is 8.4 Million needing about 4 weeks of intensive care. 20% hospitalization of 70% infected of 209.1 Million adults in the US is about 29.3 million people requiring about 4 weeks of intensive care.

A 1% fatality rate of 20% infected adults is 289,940 dead in the US. A 2% fatality rate of 70% infected adults is 2,927,400‬ dead in the US.

Normal annual fatalities in the US are 2.8 Million. These death amount to between a 10.4% increase and 104.6% increase in deaths for the year.

If we choose to control it, the control measures will directly impact production and reduce demand in an immediate fashion.

If we allow the disease to run rampant, and it actually does, the deaths and hospitalizations will pose significant disruptions; massive resource will be allocated to medical requirements, people will take time off work to care for their family members or stay in hospital, deaths will result in a significant increase in empty housing, municipal property taxes will decline (increasing the likelihood of default on municipal bonds), assets such as stocks & bonds will pour into the market either because the owner is dead or they need to pay for medical expenses.

With high debt and low savings, consumers and corporations are ill prepared to endure such an impact to production and revenue. Since we are close to full employment, have such high valuations compared to production, and have a high level of government debt already, we are primed for inflation if the government decides to print money to save these entities. In a worst case scenario, the government's credit laying could lower, and t-bonds would be dumped on the market.

However, these are all just possibilities. the chance of the worst case scenarios happening is still low; it could be contained in relatively small areas. The full potential threat may not become apparent to the non-epidemiologist for six months or so, when we have significantly more cases and their impact is directly visible. Actions such as the additional rate cuts could raise prices in the meantime.

Possible high risk long play: INGN is down to $ 47.67 from $67.59 about 8 weeks ago. They produce lightweight portable oxygen concentrators. They could have an increase in demand of orders of magnitude, in a market with a high barrier of entry (FDA regs, IP, expertise). However, they could face supply chain problems.

author: phostyle
body:
It's really a mixed bag between industries and companies when it companies' balance sheet management. And it depends on how disciplined the company's executives have been during high growth periods. Berkshire, for example, has been very discplined about its balance sheet management in recent years while Apple has been hoarding cash due to its tax strategy.

But there really isnt a right answer to any single strategy employed by businesses. Apple and Berkshire have been criticized plenty during the last five years for not generating value with their massive cash pile. Whereas Tesla was just recently praised for how quickly it was able to grow its business by leveraging with debt. At end of the day, no one has a crystal ball and businesses ought to strive for a balance.

author: wearethealienshere
body:
I gotchu. Example: 

You have an Apple worth $0.25. I say I’ll buy your Apple tomorrow for $0.50 if you give it to me today. There’s then a shortage of apples for some reason (or anything else that would drive up the demand for apples), which I’ve predicted, and I find someone willing to give me 1.00$ for the Apple. I pay you back your $0.50 and pocket the excess $0.50.  

That’s a put, unless I’m an autist. 

A call is essentially the inverse of that. If an Apple is worth $0.25 today but for some reason you think that the apples value will increase, you approach the Apple owner and say you will pay them $0.30 for an Apple tomorrow. Hopefully tomorrow you were correct in your prediction and apples are now worth $0.50, so you sell your Apple to someone else and pocket the difference

Edit: could be completely wrong tho, I am autistic

author: davidbigham

author: gopoohgo
body:
>I know fundamentals can be thrown out for now since we're trading through a pandemic, but something to keep an eye on going forward.  

Looking at historic PEs is pointless as a measure of value, because we don't have any idea what forward earnings will be.  What we do know, is bad.  

When companies like Broadcom say "yeah...uh, fuck the forward guidance, we have no idea how shitty things will get", I think waiting for market volatility to die/waiting for a floor to develop is a better plan.

author: sublimepact
body:
Yup. That's when people will know how much it is actually affecting cash flow for these corps. They usually pick on one company to trigger a tidal wave of more selling. Right now there are a few Q1 reports coming out today tomorrow, Adobe, Broadcom, not what date range Q1 2020 encompasses (some are showing as q4 2019).

Yeah keep things posted here but likely it all depends how the corporations choose to "word" their target misses, or use it to cover up or shift on the books somewhere else for a sunny day in the future.

author: JustTheWriter
body:
**Hate to get all wholesome, but rest assured I'll get back to hurling abuse at the deserving momentarily.**  

• There are likely some people out here who are being overshadowed by all the gain porn: folks who've lost their ass and might be worried as fuck. My only advice is to cut your losses and don't be ashamed or afraid to ask for help, even if it's reaching out to your fellow autists. I got crushed last fall chasing losses after CRM had their earnings call early and wrecked me. First people to reach out were people here. Messages, comments, all that. Since then, I've tried to pay that forward because it meant a lot at the time.  

• This is real life and this is real money, yes. We all know a thing or two about risk. That said, COVID19 is positioned to fuck us all with a Theta crush. Don't take your physical well-being or that physical well-being of your loved ones for granted: take care of yourselves. 

That's it. 

TL;DR: wash your fucking hands, take a deep breath. 

0327 SPY 275P

author: Captain-i0
body:
> SaaS is up like a rocket today. Appian, Okta, Splunk, Salesforce.. it's weird

They have workforces than can easily work from home. They are recurring contract based. The majority of their contracts are with large corporations that aren't going to stop using their service during a recession.  Many companies have much of their infrastructure built through these platforms. They aren't going to just kill them, unless they are completely closing up shop for good. 

They won't see as many new investments during a recession, but they aren't going to lose much in the way of customers, and some companies may use this time to spend on internal projects. I was surprised they ever were taking much of a hit in this crash to begin with. If you can get them cheap, I would.

author: trilogee
body:
* They have the higest margins of any pure play retailer in the country (excluding legacy businesses). Sequential revenue increases since company's inception.
* They have a proprietary CRM and analytics platform in hifyre that allows them to capture actionable insights on consumer spending and preferences. 
* They have the country's largest private database of retail customers through Spark Perks (over 50k members as of last q).
* With the exception of the OCS they easily have the retail industry's most accessible and optimized e-commerce platform.
* They have one of a few wholesale operations in SK which will enable them to vie for any future private wholesale decisions ON makes.  
* They have the expertise to operate with compliance, in a highly regulated market (former mettrum/emblem execs). 
* They have the backing and support of $60B retail behemoth Alimentation Couche Tard (think about all the benefits this offers in terms of real estate, operational efficiencies, network etc.) 
* They are partnered with CBRE and have access to prime real estate (<-- huge). 
* They are better capitalized than ANY other retailer in the country and even more so than most LPs.
* They have an immediately recognizable brand with search interest that far outweighs their competition (check google trends).
* CEO already forcasted profitability for Q2 2020.

No question that competition is going to be stiff - many retailers will fail; there's also room for many to succeed. Those who do will demonstrate discipline in cost control, will leverage data to order and stock products that sell, and will work with LPs to produce products that they know customers will want.

Edit: Also to be clear, there are only about 190 ROLs issued thus far. 800 applications total. 190 or less RSAs have been submitted depending on who was ready at midnight yesterday.

author: tehnoodles
body:
At a very small scale software like DNAC or DCNM works ok. Try to scale this to 10,000's of nodes, and it starts to fall apart. I have seen this multiple different times, and this was using recommended compute hardware given to us by cisco to try and make it work.

The automation software crumbles when you reach scales the require automation, which completely defeats the purpose.

I also didn't say their hardware has issues. Aside from the usual bug schedule (which cisco is no better/worse than anyone else) their hardware is rocksolid, it really comes down to the software for the API on the devices, or the software of tools to manage it.

Cisco is only a leader in the market when you look at the entire breadth of their portfolio because: No one else is spread as thin. Only Juniper comes close and IMO and while i like SRX, it's not a while lot better than Firepower. Their ability to automate though? Leaps and bounds above cisco, and their hardware platform is arguable just as mature as any that cisco has on the market.

author: tendieshitter
body:
First off, visit [optionsprofitcalculator.com](https://optionsprofitcalculator.com) to get an idea what you would make with the move of an option. It's usually difficult to calculate given all the variables, but this site should help.

" say I expect the stock to hit $35.50 at some point that day and I would  sell it, I would want to buy a put option because I expect the stock to  go down on Monday. This protects me and provides me with the opportunity  to sell my 100 shares at $36.62 still, when the current price is  $35.50. Correct? "

No. If you expect a red Monday and you already own 100 shares of Cisco you plan to sell, you are already dealing with a loss. Furthermore, if you expect the price to go down further you would be good to buy a put contract on Cisco. 

If you want to hang on to your shares of Cisco because you expect them to go up, but want "insurance" against that, you could also buy a put contract in case the price goes down.

author: SUPER_swan
body:
The ESPP program you have is a great money maker for you.


Look at the last 10 years of the stock, not the last 6 months. Cisco has slowly gone up.


Lets say your required holding period is 1 year. That means if you hold the stock for 1 year and the stock doesn’t budge in price. If you sell you gain the 15% in the discount plus 4% from the dividend you gained as well. Historically, the stock has gone up as well, which also increase your gains.

So, continue to buy your company stock.


Now there is some people I bet at your work, just like mine, that have bought their company stock for 20+ years and never sold. Doing this increasing your exposure to that one company. If the company tanks, your stock will be worth a lot less and you could be out of a job.


However, if you go with selling right after your lock out period it’s a great way to use that discount to generate more money for you. 


Relax investing is a marathon not a sprint.

author: espresso_inflective
body:
>I'm sorry, but people stuck at home won't be buying fewer Apple products to entertain themselves with, even if there is a delay in receiving the product from Apple, and Cisco won't stop building the internet that more people will use when they quarantined at home, and people won't go on Twitter less when they stuck at home, or buy less bandaids from JNJ, or stop buying laundry detergent from PG.

All of these are examples of demand shock, which I think most people agree is not the issue here. The issue is a supply shock: Apple is going to produce less, Cisco is going to have trouble obtaining their parts, Twitter's advertisers are going to experience similar shocks and buy fewer advertisements, and PG is going to have trouble sourcing the inputs for its laundry detergent.

I haven't used TD but re: RH, Fidelity is also same thing with better pre trade/after market hours + partial shares and instant deposit. No bullshit limits, no fees. Only you need good credit for margin or options and a decent history.

Also trades themselves execute MUCH better. I feel like I've been ripped off on everything I do on RH and there's this annoying delay half the time for confirmations. u/dawgsjw u/Dontcaredaily

I use fidelity. I have active trader Pro which would be similar to think or swim just on the fidelity platform. So when you make an account, you have to call them and ask for extended hours trading. It's really as easy as calling. You may have to have a minimum amount of money in the account but I honestly don't remember.

My understanding regarding the EH swings is large institutions/big buyers can cause price fluctuations based on the number of shares they buy/sell. Very few shares are traded in extended hours which is why you will see a huge price swing.

The earliest I can trade is 7am central time and as late as 7pm central time I think. I don't do after market trading so I'm not so sure on the back end
